title: A simple chapter using R
text:
This chapter is a simple example using R
You can import R package using the code

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


and then describe the purpose of your chapter as well as executing R command.
For example a basic summary of a dataset is given by

df <- read.table("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/slopp/ce3b90b9168f2f921784de84fa445651/raw/4ecf3041f0ed4913e7c230758733948bc561f434/penguins.csv", sep = "," , header = TRUE)

and produce a graph

df %>% ggplot() +
    aes(x=species, y = body_mass_g) +
    geom_boxplot()  

Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`).

title: How to contribute
text:
Create a specific branch for your chapter named an_explicit_name_for_the_branch and switch on this branch

git checkout -b an_explicit_name_for_the_branch
In the development of the project, you might find necessary to have several branches per chapter.

Create a quarto file for the chapter chapter0.qmd in your branch

git add chapter0.qmd
git commit -m "first commit in the chapter branch"

Push everything on the remote repo on Github

For the first push after the branch creation, you have to specify the name of the branch on the remote repo and you can use git  push --set-upstream origin an_explicit_name_for_the_branch or
For the push to come after the first one, you will simply push by
git  push
Once you are quite happy with your production, you will be willing to integrate your production on the main branch. A good practice is to ask the permission to push on the main branch, which is named a pull request (PR).

Ask for a PR on Github
If needed, specify in the PR message the package you need and mention MarieEtienne as reviewer of the PR.

A mock rendering of the qmd file will start when you request a PR using the Github Action mechanism (called runner on gitlab). If the action passes (green signal), you can go to the next step. If not, you will have to fix the issue (again you can ask assistance if you don’t understand the error).

Once the PR is checked, mention one of your colleage as reviewer.

title: How to contribute
text:
Create a specific branch for your chapter named an_explicit_name_for_the_branch and switch on this branch

git checkout -b an_explicit_name_for_the_branch
In the development of the project, you might find necessary to have several branches per chapter.

Create a quarto file for the chapter chapter0.qmd in your branch

git add chapter0.qmd
git commit -m "first commit in the chapter branch"

Push everything on the remote repo on Github

For the first push after the branch creation, you have to specify the name of the branch on the remote repo and you can use git  push --set-upstream origin an_explicit_name_for_the_branch or
For the push to come after the first one, you will simply push by
git  push
Once you are quite happy with your production, you will be willing to integrate your production on the main branch. A good practice is to ask the permission to push on the main branch, which is named a pull request (PR).

Ask for a PR on Github
If needed, specify in the PR message the package you need and mention MarieEtienne as reviewer of the PR.

A mock rendering of the qmd file will start when you request a PR using the Github Action mechanism (called runner on gitlab). If the action passes (green signal), you can go to the next step. If not, you will have to fix the issue (again you can ask assistance if you don’t understand the error).

Once the PR is checked, mention one of your colleage as reviewer.

title: How to contribute
text:
As a reviewer
Your role is essential as you are responsible for the quality of the submission you were assigned to. Read carefully the production and ask for correction/clarification if needed. One you are happy with the correction you can accept the PR.

title: Be ready for the course
text: The Online Collaborative Resources (OCR) class will make intensive use of the Reproducible Science tools. For this class and as an investment for the future, you will need to:

title: Be ready for the course
text:
Git on your computer
Install Git on your personal computer: Go to the Git website and click on the computer screen on the right, which should offer you the version suitable for your operating system.

title: Be ready for the course
text:
GitHub account
If you don’t have one, you have to create a GitHub account and set up the link between your computer and the GitHub. Be careful with the login you choose, this account will be used professionally and you may want to avoid pseudo like toto2024, or ladybug288.
GitHub is just one solution to share git repositories online, you may work later with gitlab with is very similar to GitHub.

title: Be ready for the course
text:
A SSH connection
To have smooth interactions with Github, you have to use a SSH and to do so, you will to generate SSH key on your computer and copy paste the public SSH key id_rsa.pub on your GitHub account.

Open a terminal (any terminal on Mac and Linux, the Git bash program you have installed with git if you are using Windows)
type the command
ssh-keygen
DO NOT ENTER ANY PASSPHRASE while asked, simply press enter (twice generally)
You should have a directory named .ssh in your main personnal folder. Open the file id_rsa.pub with any text basic editor (like notepad, gedit …) and copy the key.
Go to the settings of your GitHub account, choose the SSH and GPG keys, then press New SSH key and paste the previously copied key.

title: Be ready for the course
section: Let me know who you are
text:
Let me know who you are
Please enter your name and GitHub login on this spreadsheet and indicate in the last column whether you are already familiar with some markup languages (markdown, HTML) and if you have prior experience with Git or any version control system.
Please try to install all of this as soon as possible, and if you encounter any difficulties, don’t hesitate to contact me by email or come to me at the beginning of the class.
It will be easier if you can follow this procedure on your laptop and bring it to the class, but if you don’t have any laptop we will able to use the computers in the classroom (however this tedious installation process will have to be repeated on your personal computer)

title: A simple chapter with no code
text: This chapter is a simple example of qmd format

title: A simple chapter with no code
text:
subsection
a list

blabla
blabla 2
blabla 3

title: A simple chapter using Python
text:
This chapter is a simple example using python
You can import python librairies using the code

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

and then describe the purpose of your chapter as well as executing python command.
For example a basic summary of a dataset is given by

df = pd.read_csv("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/slopp/ce3b90b9168f2f921784de84fa445651/raw/4ecf3041f0ed4913e7c230758733948bc561f434/penguins.csv")

and produce a graph

df.boxplot(by = 'species', column = 'body_mass_g')  

<Axes: title={'center': 'body_mass_g'}, xlabel='species'>

title: The book we dreamt we had
text:
This website is produced by the M2 MODE student uring year 2023-2024 as part of their assignment in the Online Collaborative Ressources course.
They intend to develop a M1 companion book for the next student generation.
Big goal !
Please take the time to visit their production.
